bibl.title: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, March 28, 1950

div1.p: Siler does not have any recent information concerning the status of the bill in Congress honoring Reed. He offers his opinion as to how any funding should be spent. The final wording of the plaque memorializing the site of Reed's death has been agreed upon.

div1.head: Letter from J.F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, March 28, 1950
div1.opener:
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
------
GORGAS MEMORIAL LABORATORY
EXECUTIVE OFFICES
1835 EYE STREET, NORTHWEST
WASHINGTON 6, D. C.
March 28, 1950
JOSEPH F. SILER
PRESIDENT
MAURICE H. THATCHER
VICE PRESIDENT AND GENERAL COUNSEL
WALTER A. BLOEDORN
SECRETARY
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you so very much for copies of the letter to you from Mr. Wallach
and copies of your replies to him and your letter to General Reed.

I was very much interested in all of these letters and should the proposed
allocation of $350,000 pass the Congress I do so much hope that they will use
part of it as you suggest. As a matter of fact, as I wrote you recently, it seems
to me that under the present conditions from an economic standpoint and the
results to be anticipated, the expenditure of $300,000 for publicity alone would
be somewhat foolish. And, as I also wrote you before, it is my opinion that such
a fund could much better be devoted to a foundation for research work which I feel
Walter Reed himself would much prefer. I saw General Kean recently and believe
he feels somewhat as I do about this whole matter.

I have no recent information concerning the status of the bill in Congress
and should I learn anything of it I will be delighted to drop you a line.

I also wish to acknowledge receipt of the package containing the reprints
that you were kind enough to send me recently and I am passing them along to the
Surgeon General and the Commanding Officer of Walter Reed General Hospital for
proper distribution.
We finally settled the matter of the plaque by adopting the following wording:

WALTER REED
who gave man control of
YELLOW FEVER
died in a hospital on this site
November 23, 1902
We are looking forward with much pleasure to seeing you in April.

closer.signed:
J. F. Siler
Col., (MC), U.S.A, Retired
